Hobby Lobby doesn’t use barcodes: Here’s their explanation
==========================================================
by  - 05/14/23 3:06 PM ET  
...  More
by  - 05/14/23 3:06 PM ET  
...  More
Share ✕
(NEXSTAR) – There is hardly any item you can purchase that doesn’t have a barcode. In fact, getting to the checkout only to learn your item doesn’t have a barcode can prove to be a challenge.
Unless you’re shopping at a certain national retailer — then a barcode may actually be a problem.
Frequent visitors to Hobby Lobby may have noticed that their cashiers don’t scan tags but rather manually enter the item’s price and, if applicable, sale prices.
Why?
Some have speculated that Hobby Lobby, well-known for  by Evangelical Christians, fears barcodes are the “mark of the beast,” which is mentioned in the final book of the Bible. There, in , a beast is described. That apocalyptic beast would put its mark on all people, and that things could not be bought or sold “unless they had the mark.”
The idea that the barcode is a “mark of the beast” stretches back to the 1970s, according to . George Laurer, creator of the modern UPC, reportedly called the idea that it has any connection to the Bible “ludicrous.”
It’s hard to say that that lore has any impact on Hobby Lobby’s decision to not use barcodes. Former employees have debunked the claim, including TikTok user , who said the company’s owner simply believes in the power of humans over computers.
Hobby Lobby founder and CEO David Green wrote in his book, “More Than a Hobby,” that opting against barcodes and scanners at registers puts people first. He writes that he doesn’t want employees to think the company values computers over them, according to a .

metatags.twitter:description: Joe Woodland invented the bar code -- that collection of lines and numbers used to ring up your groceries every time you visit the supermarket -- and after the longtime IBMer passed away earlier this month at the age of 91, the response from certain parts of the web was all too predictable.

website_content.content:
]
Joe Woodland  -- that collection of lines and numbers used to ring up your groceries every time you visit the supermarket -- and after the longtime IBMer passed away earlier this month at the age of 91, the response from certain parts of the web was all too predictable.
"It's the mark of the beast!"  in response to our Joe Woodland tribute, pointing readers to the . Revelation is the final book of the Bible's New Testament, and among other things, it foretells an apocalypse in which a beast will rise from the earth, rain fire from the heavens, and lay his mark on all of humankind -- a mark used to buy and sell.
"He causes all, both small and great, rich and poor, free and slave, to receive a mark on their right hand or on their foreheads, and that no one may buy or sell except one who has the mark or the name of the beast, or the number of his name," reads the 13th chapter. "Let him who has understanding calculate the number of the beast, for it is the number of a man: His number is 666."
Presumably, that commenter was having a bit of fun -- he calls himself "Full Metal Pizza" and his tagline is "Soylent Green is STILL made out of people!!!" -- but ever since Woodland and his IBM colleagues introduced the Universal Product Code, they've been chased by claims that it's a step toward the apocalypse -- and not all these claims...[Content truncated]

evidence7.htmlSnippet: Jan 23, 2024 ... In the comment section of @brandy.english's video, a former Hobby Lobby employee explained, "Because there's no bar codes, the only way to raise ...

metatags.author: Abby Reinhard
metatags.og:title: Fact Check: Does Hobby Lobby Charge Different Prices for the Same Products? — Best Life
metatags.og:description: Fact Check: Does Hobby Lobby Charge Different Prices for the Same Products?
metatags.twitter:creator: @bestlifeonline

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... 
> 
In a , @brandy.english explains that she went to her local Hobby Lobby, where she confirmed that prices are different. For a package with steps for a dollhouse, one package is priced at $14.99, while the one directly behind it is $8.49.
In  from Jan. 13, TikToker @mamaericaaaa shows decorative pig figurines, one of which is $14.99 and another that is $7.99. Other videos show , including one from @thebowhuntress, where one decorative sign is $39.99 and the same one behind it is $49.99.
"Check those prices before you buy the most expensive one," @thebowhuntress cautions in the Dec. 2023 TikTok.
But is this something that happens at every Hobby Lobby location? The videos suggest it may be a larger issue—and according to former employees, pricing differences are normal.
In the comment section of @brandy.english's video, a former Hobby Lobby employee explained, "Because there's no bar codes, the only way to raise the prices on products is for the new ones to be priced higher—hence the price discrepancies on new stock."
Another added, "If they change the prices of an item, we don't take the old ones off the shelves." And yes, whatever the sticker says is what associates will manually type in at the register, regardless of any price discrepancies that appear between items on shelves.
**RELATED: **
Instead of scanning an SKU or a product code, Hobby Lobby cashiers type in prices themselves. Beyond complaints that it ends up with shoppers , rumors have also circulated that the company's Christian founders believe barcodes are the mark of the beast. However, Snopes  in July 2023, noting that there was no evidence to support the claim.
When looking at Hobby Lobby's , the company doesn't include information on why there would be different prices for the same items within stores. (It does clarify that prices, products, and promotions at brick-and-mortar stores might differ from those online.)
In terms of price matching, the company notes that it will honor competitors' ads in-store if they meet certain criteria, but within Hobby Lobby stores, the price matching policy is a bit of a gray area. In a Jan. 13 , @thebowhuntress took it upon herself to see if Hobby Lobby associates would change prices for her when purchasing two of the same item.
>             ae0fcc31ae342fd3a1346ebb1f342fcb

metatags.og:image:alt: Why Hobby Lobby‘s Doors Stay Shut on Sundays: An In-Depth Look at the Retailer‘s Unconventional Policy
metatags.twitter:title: Why Hobby Lobby‘s Doors Stay Shut on Sundays: An In-Depth Look at the Retailer‘s Unconventional Policy - Marketing Scoop
metatags.og:title: Why Hobby Lobby‘s Doors Stay Shut on Sundays: An In-Depth Look at the Retailer‘s Unconventional Policy - Marketing Scoop
metatags.og:description: Unlike other retailers of its size, Hobby Lobby does not open on Sundays. You may be wondering: why is Hobby Lobby closed on Sundays?
metatags.twitter:description: Unlike other retailers of its size, Hobby Lobby does not open on Sundays. You may be wondering: why is Hobby Lobby closed on Sundays?

website_content.content:
Hobby Lobby, the crafts and home decor chain with over 900 stores across the United States, is known for its extensive selection, regular sales, and…being closed on Sundays. Since its founding in 1972, Hobby Lobby has maintained a policy of keeping its stores shut every Sunday, bucking the retail trend of staying open seven days a week. So why does this multi-billion dollar company choose to sacrifice a day‘s worth of sales each week? The answer lies in the religious beliefs of Hobby Lobby‘s founder and CEO, David Green.
The Power of Faith-Driven Leadership
------------------------------------
Green, who started Hobby Lobby as a small home business with his wife Barbara, is an evangelical Christian. His faith has always played a central role in how he runs the company. "We believe that it is by God‘s grace and provision that Hobby Lobby has endured," Green wrote in a  posted on the Hobby Lobby website. "He has been faithful in the past, we trust Him for our future, and we give Him the glory for the achievements of the company."
For Green, closing on Sundays is a way to honor God and follow the Biblical commandment to keep the Sabbath holy. He views it as a matter of principle, even though he acknowledges that the policy has financial drawbacks for Hobby Lobby. "We‘re probably open about 66 hours a week, not 72 hours, which is a 15% cut in just being open," Green told  magazine. "We give up a lot by being closed on Sunday but we‘ve been blessed in spite of...[Content truncated]
